data.meta_description: Johnny, a young shoe salesman, is discharged from his job because of his bad memory. He finds work as a guide for an Egypt-bound tourist party led by Thomas Brooks, whose daughter, May, becomes the object of Johnny’s affection. In Egypt, Johnny meets a sheik who wishes to escape his marriage to an overweight princess. After they exchange clothes, Johnny is dismayed to find himself married. When he learns that May has been captured by desert bandits, a struggle ensues, enabling Johnny to escape his predicament and rescue May during a sandstorm. Later, Johnny discovers that his unfortunate marriage is not valid and that he is free to marry May.

The picture was announced in the 6 Nov 1926 Exhibitors Herald and 27 Nov 1926 Moving Picture World as the next starring vehicle for comedian Johnny Hines. Production company B & H Enterprises was a partnership between Hines and producer C. C. Burr. All Aboard was considered to be a working title at the time.

Principal photography began soon after at Tec-Art Studios in Hollywood, CA, as noted in the 3 Dec 1926 Film Mercury and 4 Dec 1926 Exhibitors Herald. The members of Hines’s gag-writing team were identified in the 4 Dec 1926 Motion Picture News as Peter Milne, Del Henderson, Horace Woodmansee, George Amy, and the comedian’s brother, director Charles Hines. Also joining the production were an actor listed as “France Crane,” a possible misprint of Frank Crane (4 Dec 1926 Moving Picture World); assistant director Tenny Wright (11 Dec 1926 Motion Picture News); actress Charlotte Woodbury (15 Jan 1927 [Los Angeles, CA] Evening Post-Record); actors Anna May Wong, Nola Luxford, Fred Kelsey, Charles Reed, and Bull Montana (16 Jun 1927 Film Daily); and a crew member referred to as “Doc” Travis in the 5 Feb 1927 Hollywood Topics. According to the 14 Jan 1927 and 28 Jan 1927 issues of Motion Picture News, desert sequences were filmed in El Segundo, CA, and ocean sequences were filmed in San Diego, CA, on the steamship, Yale. The production also featured a menagerie comprised of sheep, goats, camels, donkeys, horses, snakes, and Hines’s pet parrot, Loretta, who, according to the 12 Jan 1927 NYDN, was insured for $100,000. In addition, that same article claimed that Hines planned to marry his leading lady, Edna Murphy. She did marry later that year, but to director Mervyn LeRoy.

An article in the 29 Jan 1927 Moving Picture World recounted a scene, reportedly directed by Hines, in which a lion was transferred from a truck into a wooden cage. Although the approximately fifty onlookers expected the lion to quickly break out of the flimsy structure, he instead began digging in a nearby sandheap, disabling several cameras with flying debris. Hines was quickly aware of the lion’s “dramatic possibilities” and ordered the remaining cameras to continue shooting. After the scene was completed, C. C. Burr complained that he paid an exorbitant $1,000 to rent the lion, when he could have acquired many lesser specimens for $200, although he did admire the animal’s “quick” performance. The close of production was announced in the 12 Feb 1927 Exhibitors Herald. C. C. Burr later told the 25 Feb 1927 edition that he planned to cut the ten-reel picture to five and one half reels with the help of preview screenings, where he could determine what footage was expendable. The decision was prompted by an announcement from distributor First National Pictures, Inc., claiming that the public and exhibitors were demanding shorter films with “faster action.”

On 1 Apr 1927, Motion Picture News reported that the feature had recently been previewed at the Bunny Theatre in New York City. It was considered a departure from previous Johnny Hines productions, in that he established “a distinct character,” which he maintained throughout, “making a more sympathetic and cohesive story.” Peter Milne was credited with writing the subtitles.

The 6 May 1927 Motion Picture News stated that the song, “All Aboard (for a Camel Ride),” was written by Hines’s publicist, Herbert Crooker, along with composer John Milton Hagen, to coincide with the film’s release. The planned cover design would feature Hines in character.

All Aboard was released on 8 May 1927, preceded by an 18 Apr 1927 opening at the Hippodrome in New York City, and on 24 Apr 1927 at the Tower Theatre in Chicago, IL.

An unrelated short subject starring Harold Lloyd was released in 1917.

The National Film Preservation Board (NFPB) included this film on its list of Lost U.S. Silent Feature Films as of October 2019.
